title: 'Bizarre!' We don't need nurses from Spain, says Julia Hartley-Brewer | UK | News | Express.co.uk
text: 'We can train our own!' Hartley-Brewer slams 'bizarre' NHS dependence on foreign nurses 'We can train our own!' Hartley-Brewer slams 'bizarre' NHS dependence on foreign nurses JULIA HARTLEY-BREWER has rubbished the need for nurses from EU countries such as Spain, when we can train British nurses instead. PUBLISHED: 12:05, Mon, Feb 27, 2017 | UPDATED: 12:15, Mon, Feb 27, 2017 The radio host claimed nurses from Europe were not needed and that tens of thousands of people in the UK could be trained up to replace them. Her comments come as healthcare bosses have stated UK hospitals will be filled with more British nurses after Brexit . Speaking on her talkRADIO show, she said: “The idea that we need to import nurses from Spain I find utterly bizarre. BBC•GETTY Julia Hartley-Brewer has said nurses were not needed from Spain The idea that we need to import nurses from Spain I find utterly bizarre Julia Hartley-Brewer “There are tens of thousands of people who want to train as nurses in this country who aren’t allowed to because there are a limited number of training courses. “It’s not like we have a shortage of people capable or wanting to be nurses, we just don’t train up enough.” Hartley-Brewer added she was interested in Cabinet discussions on having an independent body stating how many visas should be issued for certain industries such as care and agriculture. This could also identify where there were opportunities to train up Brits. Related articles Brussels bigwig urges Remainers to stop insulting Brexit voters She said there was a lot of weariness in admitting the country was not going to see big falls in migration from inside or outside the European Union in the near future. Janet Davies, the chief executive and general secretary of the Royal College of Nursing, has said the NHS cannot be reliant on EU migrants and more incentives were needed to employ British workers as nurses. The NHS has seen a big drop in foreign workers applying for work since Britain voted to leave the EU. The Nursing and Midwifery Council has revealed 101 nurses and midwives from European countries joined the UK register in January compared to 1,304 in July 2016. Ms Davies, said the NHS had to get "far more people" trained in the UK and that recruitment drives were taking place. Related articles
